text: hi everyone I'm Veronica Dedra bellow
I'm visiting here from Michigan from the
psychology and Women's Studies joint
department and I'm gonna be telling you
about why language matters so according
to social mirroring theory our sense of
self is not simply a matter of how we
internally feel about ourselves but also
how we feel like we're viewed by others
similarly the theory of the Looking
Glass self suggests that we often think
about how we're perceived by others and
so these beliefs are known as meta
perception since their perceptions of
perception so how I think you view me
and it doesn't really matter if those
mesh or not what really matters is my
perception regardless of what you
actually think and so even though we're
often encouraged to not care about what
other people think about us this is
nearly an impossible task and research
suggests that we constantly draw upon
meta perceptions these beliefs about how
we're viewed by others in order to
create our sense of self and indeed this
serves a very important and basic human
motive to be recognized and to be viewed
as human and so in this way we are
especially motivated to seek positive
meta perceptions especially at work
where we spend most of our time and so
according to social valuing framework
employees actively interpret the meaning
of how others treat them at work to
gauge a sense of self-worth
or sense of importance accorded to them
by others and so if we're in this room
then it's not difficult for any of us to
achieve positive meta perceptions and so
although gratification is often very
delayed in academia our jobs our
prestigious weather due to our roles as
teachers and researchers and writers or
institutions like being associated with
HBS or University of Michigan however a
vast sector of the workforce is employed
in dirty work professions and so dirty
work is a theory from sociology to
describe labor that's generally
perceived as distasteful disgusting
demeaning degrading whether socially
morally or physically so this can
include jobs such as garbage collectors
sex workers loan sharks gamblers prison
guards lots of different things and so
it's been theorized that the stigma
associated with labor transfers on to
the bodies of the people performing that
labor and so I argue that this carries
really important implications for dirty
workers social mirroring and meta
perceptions as well as social valuing
and sense of self at worth so this led
me to pretty basic question
how do employees think about how others
view them and why might this matter so
to address this question I survey 200
janitors at a large Midwestern
university and guess which and as part
of this larger survey I had janitors
just fill in the blank in general people
think that janitors / custodians are
whatever and so I used a basic coding
scheme to essentially categorize these
responses so I won't go into ambivalent
but not surprisingly three quarters or
the employees provided negative words
and just under 20% shared something
positive so to start on the positive
note most of these descriptors fell into
the categories of demeanor and job mirre
job valuing excuse me so janitors are
nice cool hard-working are really
important to an effective workplace
there is more variability in the
negative responses also describing
demeanor lazy stupid classes things like
uneducated dirty work words like gross
smelly job devaluing they're not
important a child could do this type of
labor and invisible need it but not need
it but not looked at there but not there
and so I also wanted to look at what are
the consequences of negative social
mirroring and so the more negative
descriptors people provided they were
also more likely to report feeling
devalued and even reported higher
burnout and we know from the literature
that burnout is a major trigger for a
host of other psychological and
physiological consequences at work and
so taken together language is one
vehicle through which boundaries are
crafted between good work and bad work
ultimately contributing to the devaluing
of certain occupational groups and the
undermining of well-being amongst
personnel in these occupations employees
and dirty work professions are very much
aware of negative occupational
stereotypes which are not without
consequences some custodians and dirty
workers have successfully crafted
counter narratives to resist these
negative stereotypes but that's not
enough and I also show how social
mirroring as a method can be a valuable
tool to understand the prevalence and
impact of meta perceptions at work
especially among Sigma ties marginalized
and devalued personnel thank you
